de.esoco.lib.expression.monad

Interface Functor<T>

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    Monad<T,M>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Call, Option, Promise, Try

    public interface Functor<T>
    Interface of functors that wrap values of type T and allow their mapping with map(Function). This interface also defines several consuming methods like orUse(Object) and orFail() that handle the case where a functor cannot provide or determine a valid value. These methods are typically invoked at the end of a chain of mappings from one functor to another to consume the final value or react to failure to produce that value.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      <R> Functor<R> map(java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends R> fMap)
      Maps the wrapped value into a new functor instance.
      void orElse(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Throwable> fHandler)
      A consuming operation that is performed if the functor doesn't contain a valid value.
      T orFail()
      A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or throws an implementation-dependent exception if a valid value couldn't be determined.
      <E extends java.lang.Exception>
      T      		 orThrow(java.util.function.Function<java.lang.Exception,E> fMapException)
      A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or throws a mapped exception if a valid value couldn't be determined.
      T orUse(T rDefaultValue)
      A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or returns the given default value if a valid value couldn't be determined.
      default Functor<T> then(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> fConsumer)
      Consumes the value of this functor.

    • Method Detail

      • orElse

        void orElse(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Throwable> fHandler)
        A consuming operation that is performed if the functor doesn't contain a valid value. This can be used to define the alternative of a call to a monadic function like map(Function) and especially then(Consumer) to handle a failure case.
        Parameters:
        fHandler - The consumer of the the error that occurred

      • orFail

        T orFail()
  throws java.lang.Exception
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or throws an implementation-dependent exception if a valid value couldn't be determined.

        In general, calls to the monadic functions map(Function) or then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Returns:
        The functor's value
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - An exception signaling an invalid or indeterminable value

      • orThrow

        <E extends java.lang.Exception> T orThrow(java.util.function.Function<java.lang.Exception,E> fMapException)
                                   throws E extends java.lang.Exception
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or throws a mapped exception if a valid value couldn't be determined.

        In general, calls to the monadic functions map(Function) or then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Parameters:
        fMapException - A function that maps the original exception
        Returns:
        The result of the execution
        Throws:
        E - The argument exception in the case of a failure
        E extends java.lang.Exception

      • orUse

        T orUse(T rDefaultValue)
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or returns the given default value if a valid value couldn't be determined.

        In general, calls to the monadic functions map(Function) or then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Parameters:
        rDefaultValue - The value to return if no regular value could be determined
        Returns:
        The resulting value

      • map

        <R> Functor<R> map(java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends R> fMap)
        Maps the wrapped value into a new functor instance.
        Parameters:
        fMap - The value mapping function
        Returns:
        A mapped functor

      • then

        default Functor<T> then(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> fConsumer)
        Consumes the value of this functor. This method is typically used at the end of a mapping chain for the final processing of the resulting value. The default implementation invokes map(Function) with the argument consumer wrapped into a function. Some subclasses may be able to provide an optimized version. Furthermore, subclasses should typically override this method with their own type as the return type (but may just invoke the super implementation and cast the returned value).
        Parameters:
        fConsumer - The consumer of the wrapped value
        Returns:
        The resulting functor for chained invocations
